content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is very difficult for a clash of code. However, I have seen much more difficult ones, and I believe that this puzzle should not be rejected for that reason. It is a good challenge for clashers, and can really excercise their coding speed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: An interesting puzzle and a good practice

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I agree with Naknik that this should be a puzzle and not a clash of code. Not only because it could be too challenging under time pressure, but also because of the real-world relevance. As a puzzle, it would be available for everyone to visit and revisit. I know I would! :)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Too hard for CoC, maybe an easy puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice with regexp, overlaping is challenging
I think TGAGGATGCAGATCGATGATGCCTAGATGGG should read 3 ORFs
This is actually real puzzle for geneticists. This is the core of bioinformatics

Interesting clash.
At the moment "Validator - Long sequence" is the only case where you actually have to sort the results by descending order of their length. You can pass all other test cases and validators just by sorting on their index. I recommend also having a test case which checks that, as it is very easy to forget to sort, especially if you are able to pass all test cases without it.
Also, is there any particular reason to favor a 1-based index?

Seems intimidating at first but easy at the end.
Clear explanations. 

You could put the start and stop codon as constants (eg: {{ATG}}) for better readability.
A note that ORFs could overlap if they are in different reading frame would be welcome.

Thanks for your suggestions, I added the highlighting of the codons as constants and a note for the possibility of overlapping ORFs. In fact, also overlapping ORFs in the same reading frame are possible (same stop codon but different start codons) - this scenario is now also covered in a test case.

Thanks for your feedback!
I changed the (visible) test case "Long sequence" so that it also catches sorting errors. Also, I now changed the requirements to 0-based indexing because its more conventional.
Yes it is. Actually, to be more precise, one would have to also find the ORFs in the reverse strand - but I think that would be too complicated and lengthy for this clash...
